journal-meta.journal-title: The American Journal of Sports Medicine

title-group.article-title: Comparison of 2 Different Techniques for Anatomic Reconstruction of the Medial Patellofemoral Ligament
title-group.subtitle: A Prospective Randomized Study

article-meta.aff: †Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, Shijiazhuang No. 1 Hospital, Shijiazhuang, China
Investigation performed at the Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, Shijiazhuang No. 1 Hospital, Shijiazhuang, China

author-notes.corresp: *Huijun Kang, Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, Shijiazhuang No. 1 Hospital, No. 36 Fanxi Road, Shijiazhuang, 050011, Hebei, China (e-mail: doctorkanghj@yeah.net).

permissions.copyright-holder: American Orthopaedic Society for Sports Medicine

sec.title: Background:
sec.p: The comparative clinical outcome of anatomic reconstruction of the medial patellofemoral ligament (MPFL) between the Y-graft technique and C-graft technique for chronic patellar instability is unknown.

sec.title: Hypothesis:
sec.p: Anatomic reconstruction of the MPFL with a Y-graft technique (a Y-shaped graft: femoral fixation first with separate tensioning of the 2 bundles) would yield better clinical results than a C-graft procedure (a C-shaped graft: patellar fixation first with simultaneous tensioning of both bundles) for chronic patellar instability.

sec.title: Study Design:
sec.p: Randomized controlled trial; Level of evidence, 2.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: Ninety patients with symptomatic chronic patellar dislocations or instability were randomly divided into 2 groups to undergo double-bundle MPFL reconstruction either with the Y-graft technique or C-graft technique. Follow-ups were performed at 3, 6, 12, and 24 months postoperatively. The patellar stability was evaluated with the apprehension test at follow-up. The patellofemoral morphological characteristics were evaluated on axial computed tomography (CT) scans at 30° of knee flexion, and knee function was evaluated using the Lysholm and Kujala scores preoperatively and at 24 months postoperatively.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: Forty patients in the Y-graft group and 42 patients in the C-graft group were followed for 24 months. No recurrent dislocation or subluxation was reported in either group. On CT scans, congruence angle, patellar tilt angle, lateral patellar angle, and lateral displacement were restored to the normal range. The mean postoperative Lysholm scores for the Y-graft group and C-graft group were 92.3 ± 3.9 and 88.4 ± 6.8, respectively (P = .001). The mean postoperative Kujala scores were 95.9 ± 4.7 and 91.3 ± 9.7 for the Y-graft group and C-graft group, respectively (P = .001), with a good or excellent rate of 97.5% in the Y-graft group compared with 83.3% in the C-graft group (P = .031).

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: With no patellar redislocations reported, the Y-graft technique for the double-bundle anatomic MPFL reconstruction achieved statistically better knee function than the C-graft procedure at a minimum 2-year follow-up. However, the increase was less than the minimal clinically important difference, and further research is required to demonstrate its meaningful clinical improvement.

body.p: Patellofemoral joint stability results from passive soft tissue tensions of medial and lateral retinacular structures, active muscle tensions, trochlear architecture, and reactive forces acting on the articular surfaces.2 Over the past years, interest in the passive restraints of the patellofemoral joint has resulted in various techniques for reconstruction of the medial patellofemoral ligament (MPFL) to treat recurrent patellar instability, which is the primary passive restraint to lateral patellar translation at 0° to 30° of knee flexion, providing about 53% to 67% of medial soft tissue restraints.5,10,21,35

The MPFL is a compression of capsular fibers from the medial femoral epicondyle, as a distinct structure in the second layer of the medial soft tissue, attaching to the proximal two thirds of the medial border of the patella.13,29,30,38 Anatomic studies have demonstrated the concentrated functional bands of the MPFL running along its proximal and inferior edges: the inferior-straight bundle and superior-oblique bundle. The inferior-straight bundle acts as the main static soft tissue restraints, whereas the superior-oblique bundle serves as the dynamic preserver of patellar stability combined with the vastus medialis obliquus (VMO).2,13

Clinically, multiple double-bundle reconstruction procedures have been described to restore the fan-shaped insertion of the MPFL for recurrent patellar instability. The graft choice and fixation method have been studied. However, the effect of fixation sequence for the graft on the clinical outcome is still unknown, with no published reports. In our clinical practice, the reconstruction procedures have been classified into 2 types according to the fixation sequence: a Y-graft technique (a Y-shaped graft: femoral fixation first with separate tensioning of the 2 bundles) and a C-graft technique (a C-shaped graft: patellar fixation first with simultaneous tensioning of both bundles). The purpose of this prospective randomized study was to compare clinical outcomes of the double-bundle anatomic MPFL reconstruction between the Y-graft and C-graft techniques. The hypothesis was that the Y-graft technique would achieve better clinical results in patellar stability and subjective knee function than the C-graft procedure.

sec.title: Materials and Methods
sec.p: This was a prospective randomized comparative trial. All the methods described were approved by the local ethics committee, and all patients gave their informed consent to be included in the study. From June 2008 to December 2009, 90 patients with symptomatic chronic patellar dislocations or instability were randomly divided using a computer algorithm into 2 groups to undergo double-bundle MPFL reconstruction, either with the Y-graft technique (Y-graft group) or the C-graft technique (C-graft group). A symptomatic chronic patellar dislocation or instability is defined as the condition in which a patellar dislocation has occurred at least twice or patellar instability after the initial dislocation has persisted for more than 3 months after nonoperative treatment including isometric quadriceps exercises, straight-leg raises, and strengthening exercises with an emphasis on stimulation of the VMO.20 All the patients underwent the patellar apprehension test: with the knee in 30° of flexion with the quadriceps relaxed, a direct lateral force was placed on the patella, lateral translation grade (translation to one-fourth, one-half, three-fourths, and 1 of the patellar width was documented as grade I, II, III, and IV, respectively; lateral translation greater than the whole patellar width was documented as grade V; lateral translation grade greater than III was considered as abnormal), and soft versus firm end points to lateral patellar translation were evaluated by the senior author (H.J.). Radiographs and computed tomography (CT) scans were undertaken for all the patients; magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scans were only taken if there was a suspicion of an intra-articular derangement of the knee. The patellar height was evaluated on the radiographic film according to the Insall-Salvati index.12 Congruence angle, patellar tilt angle, lateral patellar angle, and lateral displacement were evaluated on the CT scans.

The exclusion criteria were as follows: (1) previous surgery on the injured knee, (2) a Q angle greater than 20° in female patients and greater than 17° in male patients, (3) a trochlear angle greater than 145°,26 (4) a tibial tuberosity–trochlear groove (TT-TG) distance ≥20 mm, (5) patella alta (Insall-Salvati index greater than 1.2), (6) patellar dysplasia grades IV and V according to the Wiberg classification,26 (7) articular cartilage erosion more severe than grade II according to the Outerbridge classification, and (8) a meniscal or tibiofemoral ligament injury requiring repair or reconstruction.

According to the exclusion criteria, 5 patients were excluded from the study: 3 patients had a TT-TG distance of greater than 20 mm, and 2 patients had articular cartilage erosion of grades III and IV. The CONSORT flow diagram is shown in Figure 1. Thus, 82 patients were analyzed for the present study. The patient demographic characteristics are displayed in Table 1, with no statistical difference between the 2 groups.

tr.td: Age at time of surgery, y

fn.label: a
fn.p: Values are expressed as mean ± standard deviation unless otherwise indicated. TT-TG, tibial tuberosity–trochlear groove.

sec.title: Surgical Technique
sec.p: All surgeries were performed by the senior surgeons. The patient was examined under anesthesia to confirm the diagnosis of a lateral patellar dislocation according to the quadripartite method. Arthroscopic surgery was first carried out to assess and address any possible chondral lesions and concomitant injuries. A medial shift of the patella less than one fourth the width of the patella indicated overtension of the lateral retinaculum. Thus, arthroscopic lateral retinacular release (LRR) was performed to decrease the tensile strength of the lateral retinaculum. The semitendinosus tendon autograft was harvested using a closed-end tendon stripper in a standard fashion as in an anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction.

In the C-graft group (Figure 2), the 2 ends of the tendon were sutured with a whipstitch technique using No. 2 nonresorbable sutures about 25 mm in length. The graft was prepared with a C-shape. The 2-incision approach was preferred: The first 3-cm longitudinal incision was along the proximal medial border of the patella, and the other 1-cm incision was above the MPFL femoral insertion. The retinaculum and periosteum of the medial patellar rim were incised longitudinally and elevated off the bone. A superficial longitudinally bony sulcus at the proximal half of the medial patellar rim was created using a rongeur with a length of 15 to 18 mm, width of 4 to 5 mm, and depth of 3 to 4 mm. The middle of the graft was placed in the bony sulcus with 2 limbs close to the superomedial corner and the midpoint of the medial patellar border. The prepatellar fascia was sutured by 3 No. 2 nonresorbable sutures. The first 2 sutures were proximal and distal to the bony sulcus to embed the graft in the bony sulcus. The third suture was in the middle of the bony sulcus and through the graft to prevent its slide. The retinaculum and periosteum were sutured on the top of the graft for additional fixation. With isometry in consideration, the femoral origin of the MPFL resided in the saddle between the adductor tubercle and medial epicondyle. The isometric point was identified using a previously reported method.39 A 7-mm reamer was used to drill a tunnel over the guide pin to a depth of 25 mm. Blunt dissection was carried out to create a soft tissue tunnel from the medial patellar border to the medial epicondyle, deep to the medial retinaculum but superficial to the synovium, and the 2 free ends were passed under the VMO and fascia to the adductor tubercle. The graft was pretensioned through several flexion-extension cycles, and isometry was reconfirmed. The graft was then fixed by an interference screw at about 30° of knee flexion, where the patella was stabilized into the femoral groove, which was monitored under arthroscopic surgery. The lower border of the VMO was advanced 5 to 10 mm distally and laterally and sutured on the superior limb of the graft at 20 mm close to its patellar insertion.

caption.p: Schematic diagrams of the C-graft technique for anatomic medial patellofemoral ligament reconstruction. (A) The C-shaped graft. (B) Anteromedial view showing the C-shaped graft embedded in the bony sulcus with 2 limbs close to the superomedial corner and the midpoint of the medial patellar border. The graft was sutured to the prepatellar fascia and retinaculum by 3 No. 2 nonresorbable sutures. (C) Axial view showing the graft placed deep into the medial retinaculum and superficial to the synovium, fixed in the blind femoral tunnel with an interference screw.

sec.p: For the Y-graft technique (Figure 3), the tendon was folded from the middle and sutured with a whipstitch technique using No. 2 nonresorbable sutures about 25 mm in length. The graft was prepared into a horizontal Y-shape. The 2-incision approach was similar to the C-graft technique with the femoral incision first. After the isometric femoral insertion point was identified using the previous method, the femoral tunnel was drilled, and the folded end of the graft was fixed by an interference screw, similar to the closed technique. Then, the 2 free ends were passed through the soft tissue tunnel to the medial patellar edge. The inferior bundle was sutured firstly to the midpoint of the medial patellar margin with the knee at complete extension. The graft was inserted beneath the peripatellar retinaculum and out from the midline of the prepatellar fascia and sutured back to the top of the graft with the whipstitch suture. Then, the superior bundle was fixed to the superomedial corner in a similar fashion with knee flexion at 30°. In addition, the lower border of the VMO was advanced 5 to 10 mm distally and laterally and sutured on the superior bundle graft about 20 mm.

caption.p: Schematic diagrams of the Y-graft technique for anatomic medial patellofemoral ligament reconstruction. (A) The horizontal Y-shaped graft. (B) Anteromedial view showing the double bundles of the graft that were sutured to the midpoint of the medial patellar margin and the superomedial corner with the whipstitch suture. (C) Axial view showing the graft that was inserted beneath the peripatellar retinaculum and out from the midline of the prepatellar fascia and sutured back to the top of the graft. The blind femoral tunnel was fixed with an interference screw.

sec.title: Postoperative Rehabilitation and Clinical Evaluations
sec.p: After MPFL reconstruction, all patients followed the same rehabilitation protocol. The quadriceps setting and straight-leg raising exercises to strengthen the muscle from the day after surgery were encouraged. Static partial weightbearing was also permitted on an as-tolerated basis with the knee in extension with a simple knee brace. Walking with weightbearing on 2 crutches was also started and gradually progressed. Range of motion exercises were initiated about 3 days after surgery. Functional activities including walking, jogging, and running were introduced at 3 months postoperatively, when patients achieved sufficient range of motion, muscle strength, and stability. Typically, 6 months were needed for patients to return to normal sports activities.

In the follow-up, patellar stability was evaluated with the apprehension test and patients were divided into 3 groups as stability, subluxation, and redislocation.4 Based on the partition of lateral translation grade, grades I and II with a hard end point were considered as stability, grade III with a hard end point was considered as subluxation, and a soft end point was considered as redislocation. A grade greater than III was also considered as redislocation. The patellofemoral structural characteristics were evaluated on an axial CT scan at 30° of knee flexion, on which congruence angle, patellar tilt angle, lateral patellar angle, and lateral displacement were measured with the method described by Kujala et al.15 In addition, the Lysholm score and Kujala score were used for subjective knee function. A Kujala score of 95 points or more is excellent, 94 to 85 is good, 84 to 65 is fair, and 64 or less is poor.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: Before the investigation, the sample size was estimated using the Kujala score as the primary variable. On the basis of previous clinical experience, the standard deviation was assumed at 15 points. A power calculation was performed with a confidence level of 95% (α = .05) and a power (1 – β) of 80%. This yielded an estimated sample size of 37 patients per group. The statistical analysis was performed with SPSS 13.0 software (SPSS Inc, Chicago, Illinois). The Kolmogorov-Smirnov test was used to test the normality of the variances. The t test was for the parametric variances, and the Mann-Whitney U test and χ2 test were for nonparametric variances. Significance was set at P ≤ .05.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: All the postoperative follow-ups were conducted by the same senior surgeons. Forty patients in the Y-graft group and 42 patients in the C-graft group were followed for 24 months. There was no infection, chronic effusion, or synovitis reported at the time of follow-up. At the final follow-up, all the patients had restored full range of motion.

At surgery, arthroscopic cartilage lesions on the patellofemoral joint were observed in 75% of patients in the Y-graft group and 71.4% in the C-graft group (P = .989). All the cartilage lesions were Outerbridge grade I or II. No loose osteochondral fragments were found, and simple debridement was performed without an additional microfracture or osteochondral transplantation (Table 2).

Arthroscopic LRR was performed for 42.5% of patients in the Y-graft group and 38.1% in the C-graft group, without a significant difference between the groups (P = .684). Regarding the effects of arthroscopic LRR, 33 patients who underwent LRR were defined as the LRR(+) group, while the 49 patients without the LRR procedure were the LRR(−) group. No signiﬁcant differences were found between the LRR(+) and LRR(−) groups in the preoperative and postoperative knee functional scores (Table 3).

caption.p: Results of Knee Function Between the LRR (+) and LRR (–) Groups a

fn.label: a
fn.p: Values are expressed as mean ± standard deviation unless otherwise indicated. LRR, lateral retinacular release.

fn.label: b
fn.p: Comparative results between preoperative and 24-month follow-up.

sec.p: The CT measurement results of the congruence angle, lateral patellar angle, patellar tilt angle, and lateral displacement were similar between the 2 groups before surgery. Immediately after surgery, the degree of these 3 angles and lateral patellar displacement returned to a similar range in both groups, without a significant difference between the groups. At 24-month follow-up after surgery, the patella was displaced and tilted laterally. However, significant improvement was still seen between the preoperative CT measurement results and 24-month follow-up in the 2 groups (Table 4).

caption.p: Patellofemoral Measurements on Computed Tomography a

fn.label: a
fn.p: Values are expressed as mean ± standard deviation unless otherwise indicated.

fn.label: b
fn.p: Comparative results between preoperative and 24-month follow-up.

sec.p: At final follow-up, no patients suffered from a patellar redislocation or subluxation. Significant improvement in knee function in the Lysholm and Kujala scores was seen after surgery in the 2 groups (Table 5). The mean postoperative Lysholm scores for the Y-graft group and C-graft group were 92.3 ± 3.9 and 88.4 ± 6.8, respectively (P = .001). The mean postoperative Kujala scores were 95.9 ± 4.7 and 91.3 ± 9.7 for the Y-graft group and C-graft group, respectively (P = .001), with a good or excellent rate of 97.5% in the Y-graft group compared with 83.3% in the C-graft group (P = .031).

caption.p: Results of Knee Function at Follow-up a

fn.label: a
fn.p: Values are expressed as mean ± standard deviation unless otherwise indicated.

fn.label: b
fn.p: Comparative results between preoperative and 24-month follow-up.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Recurrent patellar dislocations are relatively common after a primary dislocation, with reported rates of 17% to 45%17,18 attributed to a variety of anatomic factors. Trochlear dysplasia, patella alta, an increased TT-TG distance of greater than 20 mm, and soft tissue abnormalities such as a torn MPFL and inadequate VMO are all factors to be considered.3,11,18 Cadaveric studies have demonstrated that the MPFL provides 50% to 60% of the soft tissue restraint to lateral translation.5 Surgical explorations and MRI have addressed the essential pathological MPFL lesions in knees with acute patellar dislocations.1,37 Recurrent patellar dislocations may result when the MPFL fails to heal or heals in a lengthened position. Therefore, reconstruction of the MPFL might be an effective way to restore normal peripatellar anatomy and its function, with encouraging clinical outcomes.

Clinically, various surgical procedures have been described for MPFL reconstruction. As an extra-articular procedure, the graft may be placed with either a patellar or femoral fixation first during surgery. No published works have revealed the effect of the fixation sequence on the clinical outcome. In the present study, the surgical procedure was classified into 2 types according to the fixation sequence of the graft. It is the first classification in the literature for a double-bundle MPFL reconstruction. The comparisons between the 2 techniques are summarized in Table 6. The main difference was that the Y-graft technique started with femoral fixation first, with the double bundles tensioned separately at different knee flexion angles, while the C-graft technique began with the patellar fixation first, with the double bundles tensioned synchronously. Based on the anatomic difference of the concentrated functional bands of the MPFL, the Y-graft technique was not only an anatomic reconstruction but also a functional reconstruction.

caption.p: Summaries of the Y-Graft and C-Graft Techniques

tr.td: Bone tunnel with an interference screw
Bone tunnel with an interference screw
Sutured with the peripatellar retinaculum and prepatellar fascia
Sutured with the prepatellar fascia in a bony sulcus
Inferior bundle: knee at complete extension; superior bundle: knee flexion at 30°
Both double bundles: knee flexion at 30° synchronously

sec.p: According to our classification for the MPFL reconstruction, the C-graft technique has been adopted by many surgeons. Among all the previous reports, the technique of 2 divergent patellar transverse tunnels with the graft looped around was the most popular, which was a reliable management option with encouraging results reported. Panni et al25 reported the results of 33 months’ follow-up with no patellar redislocation, with an overall patient satisfaction rate of over 80%. The mean Kujala score improved significantly from 56.7 to 86.8 points, and the mean modified Lysholm score improved from 57.6 to 88.1 points. Ronga et al31 reported that 3 patients (3/28) experienced patellar redislocations at a mean 3.1 years’ follow-up. The mean modified Cincinnati score increased from 52 to 89 points and the mean Kujala score from 45 to 83 points. Han et al8 reported on a mean follow-up of 5.7 years with 6 patients (6/52) with an occasional unstable feeling without redislocations recorded. The mean modified Cincinnati score increased from 50.6 to 88.7 points and the mean Kujala score from 41.4 to 82.6 points. To avoid a transverse patellar fracture, Siebold et al36 described the transosseous suture technique similar to our C-graft technique instead of the bone tunnel procedure without follow-up results reported. The present improvement in knee function in the mean Kujala score from 52.5 to 91.3 points and the mean Lysholm score from 50.3 to 88.4 points showed similar results with the bone tunnel technique.

In our new Y-graft technique with the double bundles of the graft tensioned separately at knee flexions of 0° and 30°, good clinical results were obtained with the Kujala score of 95.9 points, with a good or excellent rate of 97.5%. This result is comparable with recent clinical studies. Kita et al14 reported on their Y-graft technique with a double-bundle graft tensioned to the patella by an EndoButton at 45° of knee ﬂexion, evaluated by second-look arthroscopic surgery 1 year after the initial surgery. Although patellar tracking in 16 knees (16/25) was a little laterally shifted after reconstruction and 3 patients still had positive apprehension signs, no patients reported redislocations, and the median Kujala score improved significantly from 73 points (range, 66-82 points) to 95 points (range, 85-100 points). Similar to our Y-graft technique, Deie et al6 also sutured the double bundles of the graft at the insertion site of the patellar medial ridge with the knee flexed at 30°, and 30 of 31 patients showed good clinical results, with the mean Kujala score improving significantly from 64 points (range, 35-70 points) to 94.5 points (range, 79-100 points) after 3.2 years. There were no patellar redislocations and only 1 patient with a Kujala score of 79 points with an apprehension sign due to feeling medial instability.

Patellofemoral contact begins with the distal part of the patella at approximately 20° of ﬂexion, and it progresses to the proximal pole of the patella at 90° of ﬂexion.32 With knee ﬂexion, the VMO starts to contract; the superior-oblique bundle is not only a static structure but also serves as a dynamic preserver of patellar stability combined with the VMO, and the inferior-straight bundle acts as the main static soft tissue restraint.13 A biomechanical study28 has revealed that the single-bundle technique did not restore normal patellar tracking at any flexion angle, whereas the Y-graft double-bundle technique restored statistically normal patellar tracking from maximal extension to 28° of flexion; beyond 28° of flexion, the patella slips into the femoral trochlear groove, and the resultant lateral force is resisted by the prominent lateral facet of the femoral trochlea. For the C-graft surgical procedure, the double bundles of the graft were tensioned by femoral fixation synchronously in a single-bundle fashion. To a certain extent, it can be interpreted as a single-bundle reconstruction with a wide graft without restoring the functional bundles of the native MPFL.

Normal physiological patellar tracking is complex and characterized by a decreasing patellar flexion angle, decreasing lateral rotation, lateral tilt, and medial shift of the initially laterally placed patella during knee extension.7 Comparing the patellar kinematics of the intact and resected MPFL in a lateral unloaded condition, Zaffagnini et al43 showed the initial lateral shift of the patella between 0° and 30° of knee flexion, without signiﬁcant differences. On the other hand, Ostermeier et al22 reported a statistically signiﬁcant lateral shift of 4.0 ± 2.5 mm at 9.1° of knee ﬂexion. Therefore, patellar stability at 0° and 30° of knee flexion was needed to be considered simultaneously in the MPFL reconstruction. Fortunately, the Y-graft technique consisted of the double bundles of the graft tensioned for patellar fixation: the inferior-straight bundle was fixed at 0° of flexion to maintain the static restraints, and the superior-oblique bundle was fixed at 30° of flexion with VMO advancement to its dynamic restraints, which may better restore normal patellar kinematics.

Anatomic studies have shown that the VMO, the inferior portion of the vastus medialis, blends with the superior border of the MPFL.1,13,29,30 The VMO, as a dynamic medial stabilizer, may work in concert with the MPFL to draw the slightly lateralized patella to the trochlea during early knee flexion.24 In a recent clinical study, Wang et al39 observed superior functional results in patients undergoing a combined MPFL reconstruction with VMO advancement. However, their study was based on the single-bundle reconstruction. In the present study, the VMO was advanced and sutured on the superior bundle of the double-bundle graft, which restored the MPFL function in a more dynamic fashion with both the Y-graft and C-graft techniques.

We have to consider the inﬂuence of the LRR on the clinical results for the 40.4% of patients who underwent additional arthroscopic LRR in the present study. The effect of an LRR on patellar instability has been controversial. An in vitro study suggested that an LRR did not inevitably stabilize or medialize patellar tracking through the entire knee extension cycle but could decrease pressure on the lateral patellar facet in knee flexion.23 Thus, the LRR is best performed in patients with a stable patella and a tight lateral retinaculum and excessive lateral pressure, as confirmed by Panni et al,27 with less favorable long-term results in patellar instability. Comparable with the results of Watanabe et al,41 no significant difference of knee function between the LRR(+) and LRR(−) groups was shown and no inﬂuence of the LRR on the clinical MPFL reconstruction. An isolated LRR has little or no role in the treatment of acute or recurrent patellar instability. However, it can be added as an adjunct procedure to the MPFL reconstruction for a contracted lateral retinaculum because of chronically ruptured MPFLs.16

Basic science and anatomic reconstruction of the MPFL have received increased attention and resulted in numerous surgical techniques. However, there is no agreement regarding the optimum method for MPFL reconstruction. With both the Y-graft and C-graft techniques, the femoral tunnel was in the saddle between the adductor tubercle and medial epicondyle and evaluated according to Schoettle et al’s34 radiographic method. The patellar insertion was positioned at the midpoint and the superomedial corner of the medial patellar border. No misposition or patellar fracture was reported. Up to now, the patellar fixation method had still been a matter of debate with the transverse 2-tunnel technique,8,25,31 suture anchors,33 and so on. In the present study, soft tissue suture fixation was used to avoid the problems that fixation devices such as suture anchors or buttons may have in leading to foreign body reactions and accidental ablation of the anterior or chondral surface of the patella related to transverse patellar tunnels. A biomechanical study showed that the strength of the human MPFL was 208 N, and the suture repair failed at a mean of 37 N,19 which is significantly weaker than the MPFL. However, Yang et al42 recently reported that the strength of the 4-suture method, in the fashion of the C-graft technique, was 239.57 N, which is significantly higher than the native MPFL of 145.91 N and the suture-anchor technique of 159.17 N. Clinically, many follow-ups with encouraging results have also relieved the worry about the strength of soft tissue suture fixation.39-41

The present study has some limitations: the first was the short follow-up time to evaluate the recurrence rate. There is a tendency for redislocations to occur with a longer follow-up time.9 With a minimum follow-up of 2 years, the short follow-up might explain the better results in the present study. The second was that it was not a double-blind design, which may result in a bias in clinical examinations for patellar stability. The third was that the patellar tilt and shift were evaluated in the measurements of the CT scans. Although patellar rotation was difficult to assess at present, the evaluation of patellar rotation in the future may better reveal patellar tracking after MPFL reconstruction.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: With no patellar redislocations reported, the Y-graft technique for anatomic double-bundle MPFL reconstruction achieved statistically better knee function than the C-graft procedure at a minimum 2-year follow-up, with a mean Lysholm score of 92.3 ± 3.9 versus 88.4 ± 6.8 (P = .001) and a mean Kujala score of 95.9 ± 4.7 versus 91.3 ± 9.7 (P = .001), respectively. However, the increase is less than the minimal clinically important difference, and further research is required to demonstrate its meaningful clinical improvement.

ack.p: The authors thank Professor Xu Zheng for drawing the schematic diagram in the article.

fn.p: The authors declared that they have no conflicts of interest in the authorship and publication of this contribution.
